notesStmt.note: Consists primarily of the reply by Charles I, with a cover letter of 15 Sept. 1647 containing the Army's proposals, and a final note signed by Jo: Hall, 15 Sept. 1647.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: NEW PROPOSITIONS FROM His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, Lieutenant Generall Cromwell, and the Councell of the Army, concerning the Kings Maje≈øty, His Royall Con≈øort the Queene, Charles Prince of Wales, and James Duke of York, Pre≈øented to His Maje≈øty at Hampton-Court. With His Maje≈øties Gracious An≈øwer and De≈øires.

figure.head: C R
figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE
figure.figDesc: English royal blazon surmounted by a crown

div.p: 7ber 16. Printed at London, for Robert William≈øon, 1647.

div.head: ANOTHER MESSAGE FROM The Kings Maje≈øty at Hampton-Court: Sent to the Honourable Hou≈øe of Peeres, together with his new propo≈øitions, and De≈øires therein.
Inclo≈øed in a Letter from Hampton-Court, September, 15.
div.p:
YOu have ever pur≈øued me with your favours, that I am made capable of no other plea≈øure in the world but to entertain them: in≈øomuch, that ≈øhould I offer up my being to you, tis impo≈ø≈øible for me, but in part to di≈ø-ingage my ≈øelfe; ≈øo that of nece≈ø≈øity I mu≈øt want both words and ≈øervices to expre≈ø≈øe how unfeinedly I honour you: Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I ≈øhall embolden my ≈øelf, to make my earne≈øt de≈øire
vi≈øible unto you, by imparting that, which all Loyal Subjects de≈øires to be partakers of; and therefore, for generall ≈øatisfaction to your ≈øelfe, and the whole Kingdome, I thought it expedient to communicate his Maje≈øties la≈øt Me≈ø≈øage and Re≈øolution unto you, that ≈øo the whole Kingdome may take notice of His gracious inclination towards a firme and well ≈øetled Peace, together with His Maje≈øties Propo≈øalls and De≈øires therein, to His two Hou≈øes of Parliament a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter, and how far He declares him ≈øelf for the Army; All which I ≈øhall make manife≈øt in his Maje≈øties inclo≈øed Me≈ø≈øage, ≈øigned Charles Rex.
In the intrim, I humbly crave your favourable ac-acceptation, to vouch≈øafe the ≈øerious peru≈øall of the≈øe en≈øuing Propo≈øals, to which, his Maje≈øty doth ≈øo well approve of, viz.
1. An Act to be pa≈ø≈øed to take away all coercive power, authority, and juri≈ødiction of Bi≈øhops, and all other Eccle≈øia≈øticali Officers what≈øoever, extending to any civill penalties upon any.

2. That there be a repeale of all Acts or Clau≈øes in any Act enjoyning the u≈øe of the Booke of Common-Prayer, and impo≈øing any penalties for neglect thereof, as al≈øo of all Acts or Clau≈øes in any Act, impo≈øing any penalties for not coming to Church, or for meetings el≈øe-where, for prayer, or other religious duties.

3. That the taking of the Covenant be not inforced upon any, or any penalties impo≈øed upon the Refu≈øers, whereby men might be con≈øtrained to take it again≈øt their judgments, or con≈øciences, but all Orders oa Ordinances, tending to that purpo≈øe to be repealed.

4. That (the things here-before propo≈øed, being provided, for ≈øetling and ≈øecuring the Rights, Liberties, Peace, and ≈øafety of the Kingdom) his Maje≈øties per≈øon, his Queen, and royall i≈ø≈øue may bee re≈øtored to a condition of ≈øafety, honour, and freedome in this Natton, without dimunition to their per≈øonall rights, or further limitation, to the exerci≈øe of the Regall power, than according to the particulars aforegoing.
5. That there may be a generall Act of Oblivion to extend unto all, &c.

All which Propo≈øals, together with many others, were debated and agreed upon, by the Generall, and the Councell of his Army, and pre≈øented to the Kings mo≈øt gracious Maje≈øty; who after ≈øome peru≈øall of the ≈øame, his Maje≈øty declared a great affection towards them, and immediatly declared him≈øelf to both Hou≈øes of Parliament, as followeth:

div.head: His Maje≈øties gracious Me≈øsage (or Declaration) to His two Hou≈øes of Parliament a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter.
div.p:
HIs Maje≈øty cannot choo≈øe but bee pa≈ø≈øionately ≈øen≈øible (as hee believes all his good Subjects are) of the late great di≈øtractions, and ≈øtill langui≈øhing and un≈øetled State of this Kingdome; And Hee calls God to witne≈ø≈øe, and is willing to give te≈øtimony
to all the world of his readine≈ø≈øe to contribute his utmo≈øt endeavours for re≈øtoring it to a happy & flouri≈øhing condition.

His Maje≈øty having peru≈øed the Propo≈øitions now brought to him, ≈øinds them the ≈øame in effect which were offered to him at Newca≈øtle. To ≈øome of which, he could not then con≈øent without violation of his con≈øcience and honour; ≈øo can hee neither agree to others now, conceiving them in many re≈øpects more di≈øproportionable to the pre≈øent condition of affaires then when they were formerly pre≈øented to him, as being de≈øtructive to the many principall intere≈øts of the Army, and of all tho≈øe who≈øe affections concurre with them.

And his Maje≈øty having ≈øeene the Propo≈øals of the Army to the Commi≈ø≈øioners of his two Hou≈øes re≈øiding with them, and with them to be treated on, in order to the clearing and ≈øecuring the rights and Liberties of the Kingdome, as the ≈øetling of a ju≈øt and la≈øting Peace.

To which Propo≈øals, as he conceives his two Hou≈øes not to be ≈øtrangers, ≈øo he believes they will thinke with him, that they much more conduce to the ≈øati≈øfaction of all intere≈øts, and may bee a fitter foundation for a la≈øting peace, then the Propo≈øitions which at this time are tendred to him.

He therefore propounds (as the be≈øt way in His judgment in order to Peace) that his two Hou≈øes would in≈øtantly take into con≈øideration tho≈øe Propo≈øals upon which there may be a per≈øonall treaty with his Maje≈øty, and upon ≈øuch other Propo≈øalls as his Maje≈øty ≈øhall make, hoping that the ≈øaid Propo≈øals may be ≈øo moderated in the ≈øaid treaty, as to render
them the more capable of his Maje≈øties full conce≈ø≈øions, wherein hee re≈øolves to give full ≈øatisfaction to his People for what≈øoever ≈øhall concerne the ≈øetling of the Prote≈øtant Profe≈ø≈øion, with liberty to tender Con≈øciences, and the ≈øecuring of the Lawes, Liberties, and properties; of all his Subjects, and the ju≈øt priviledges of Parliament for the future.

And likewi≈øe by his pre≈øent deportment in this treaty, hee will make the world clearly judge of his intentions in matter of future Government; In which treaty his Maj. will be plea≈øed (if it be thought fit) that Commi≈ø≈øioners from the Army (who≈øe the Propo≈øals are) may likewi≈øe be admitted.

His Maje≈øty therefore conjures his two Hou≈øes of Parliament, by the duty they owe to God, and his Maje≈øty their King, and by the bowels of compa≈ø≈øion they have to their fellow ≈øubjects, both for reliefe of their pre≈øent ≈øufferings, and to prevent future mi≈øeries, that they will forthwith accept of his Maje≈øties offer, whereby the joyfull newes of peace may bee re≈øtored to this di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Kingdome. And for what concernes the Kingdom of Scotland mentioned in the Propo≈øitions, his Maje≈øty will very willingly treate upon tho≈øe particulars with the Scotch Commi≈ø≈øioners; and doubts not but to give rea≈øonable ≈øatisfaction to that his Kingdome.

postscript.head: For the Right Honourable, the Earl of Manche≈øter, Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Peeres, pro tempore, to be communicated to both Hou≈øes of the Parliament of England,and the Commi≈øsioners of the Kingdome of Scotland,
postscript.p: IT is hoped that this An≈øwer will give very much ≈øatisfaction to the Kingdome, and therefore I de≈øire you to u≈øe your utmo≈øt endeavours for the publi≈øhing thereof, that ≈øo the world may take notice of the great forwardne≈ø≈øe and readine≈ø≈øe of his Maje≈øty to contribute his utmo≈øt endeavours for re≈øtoring of this poor langui≈øhing kingdome to a happy and flouri≈øhing condition, and al≈øo the reall and candid intentions of the Army, towards his Maje≈øty, the Queen, and Royal I≈ø≈øue. Thus, for the pre≈øent, I mu≈øt re≈øtrain my pen, but ≈øhall for ever hereafter ≈øet my hand to the Paper, to expre≈ø≈øe how much I am

closer.signed: Your faithfull friend and ≈øervant, Jo: Hall.
